title: Monday, 4th February 2019
bodyHTML:

And to reiterate previous warnings, your comments on the right may disappear at short notice. We're not here to wear your risk.

https://www.ft.com...-a5ab-ff8ef2b976c7

German payments provider Wirecard on Monday morning told investors that an external law firm has been investigating alleged accounting manipulations by “a member of Wirecard’s finance team” in its Singapore operations since May 2018, with the probe still ongoing.

cheeckychappy @Brycey - so that sounds like a confirmation of last week's Wirecard story
BE11:17am

Subtly different approach to the statement than some of the wire coverage this morning.

cheeckychappy ?
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Which I guess is what happens when you read what's actually written rather than going by tone.

Shinshin Always amusing to see the defence of "well they would say that they have a short position". Because I for one definitely take out shorts on a whim then go looking for a reason.
Grouchmonkey “Reaching out” be?
BE11:18am

If you want to read the actual statement, it's here: https://ir.wirecar...tml?newsID=1751501

BornCynic Just reading the Alphaville link to David Henig (twitter) on the list of things that will happen on a no deal Brexit. Not fun reading.............
FATDAZ on the subject of fallout from dubious accounting the BBC news website had several stories about (now former) Pat val employees being further shafted by not getting back pay or redundancy

And if you want a "buy" note from the sellside analysts at Handelsblatt, that's here: https://www.handel...siko/23944646.html

Pharma @FATDAZ, was surprised at that. Would have thought it would put the directors in the firing line for running an insolvent company.
Irish HF guy Wirecard : "We fundamentally contradict the reporting of Dan McCrum"
Soundbuy How's the pension situation at Pat Val?
11:20 am
BE11:20am

Which is, in effect, backing up the detail of the FT's stories last week (albeit with the occasional oddity, such as saying the preliminary report was "based at that time only on statements of the Whistleblower") ......

wayneJ @Irish HF Guy - I thought that sentence was 'interesting' - now targetting Dan
FATDAZ @Pharma yes it all sounded very unsatisfactory and obviously v hard on the ex staff
Irish HF guy it is clearly written by a German!
BE11:22am

.... but wrapping it into an interview with Markus Braun and editorialising about unknowns in a way that probably wouldn't fly in a British newspaper.

BE11:23am

You'll remember Wirecard dismissed the FT's reports last week as "inaccurate, misleading and defamatory"

FATDAZ @BE I see HSBC had a note out on Wirecard today as well
Grouchmonkey Scadenfreude
wayneJ @BornCynic - David Hening is better informed that many - extremely good - worth following

11:24 am

But don't seem to have offered anything specific to suggest they were inaccurate, misleading and defamatory. Depending, I guess, on your definitions of words like "conclusive" and "preliminary" .......

BornCynic @waynej - he appears to be talking sense, but I am no expert..........
wayneJ Shall we start the 'Dan is innocent / Dan is right' campaign?
BE11:25am

..... Suggesting the reports were, as we already knew, accurate, leading and famatory.

BE11:25am

Anyway. Let's see what the sellside's saying.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

(@Wayne: please don't. At least not here.)

BE11:26am

Morgan Stanley .....

BE11:27am

Wirecard has this morning issued a rebuttal to comments made in the Financial Times last week. It has stated that in April 2018, an employee “raised concerns” of a compliance breach to its local legal team in Singapore. The allegations relate to breaches of accounting procedure over 2015-18 and total revenues of €6.9m (0.3% of FY19e revenues), costs of €4.1m and an internal transfer of software IP of €2.6m. Wirecard said it launched an internal investigation, which found no evidence to support the allegation and “concluded that they were unfounded”, indicating that the allegations could relate to “personal animosity” between employees. In line with its compliance procedures, Wirecard mandated Rajah & Tann, a Singapore based law firm, to carry out an independent investigation, which is ongoing. On this, Rajah & Tann has also issued a statement, highlighting that the enquiry is ongoing and that “to date we have made no conclusive findings of criminal misconduct on the part of any officer or employee of the Company”

11:27 am
BE11:27am

.... offering absolutely no view and no editorialising.

BE11:27am

Kepler ......

BornCynic Talking of Brexit - anyone else feel like loading up on the USD and waiting for the politicians to get it horribly wrong?
BE11:28am

While everything is still possible, the amounts in question are fairly low and
the potential compliance breaches issue seems to be potentially coming from
individuals and not management.

chad_john BornCynic - that, but GBP
11:28 am
BE11:28am

"While everything is still possible" ...... K.

chad_john Cracking time to buy if you've got nerve / deep pockets / a pessimistic outlook on our national government
BE11:28am

Kempen ......

BE11:28am

In our view, the nature of the
allegations involved concern an individual's actions and if proven true could
result in a fine which is either S$1m or twice the amount misappropriated
funds. However, we await further clarity by the company and investigation
by Singaporean authorities as it is too early to conclude on the impact
of such allegations.

wayneJ If that E6.9M referred to in the Wirecard statement is really revenue then the 'transaction volume' reported would be an order of magnitude bigger than that - or am I missing something?
11:28 am
BE11:29am

Wee bit of a change of tone from last week's coverage, that.

Excel Developer @chad_john: I'm confused if Brexit is bad GBP will tank, so why buy GBP assets?
wayneJ At 4% transaction fee - say - it would be 172m? or am I misunderstanding?
chad_john @Excel On the assumption it won't happen, or at least if it does it'll be far softer than currently being offered.
BE11:30am

HSBC .....

BE11:30am

Back to fundamentals: On 30 January, Wirecard announced preliminary 2018 results that were broadly in line with our and consensus estimates. Guidance for 2019 was reiterated (EBITDA range EUR740-800m). We make only slight adjustments to our estimates. More details (the take rate in Q4 2018, and margins by business) will be given with the full results on 4 April. During 2018-20e, we expect average top-line growth of 30% pa and the EBITDA margin to expand to 30% in 2020e from 27.3% in 2018e, leading to an EPS CAGR of 33% pa (previously 32%). Our 2020e revenue estimate is 11% above guidance due to a more resilient take rate assumption and we are broadly in line with consensus.
Maintain Buy rating and EUR240 TP: With only minor estimate changes, our DCFbased TP remains EUR240, which implies 122% upside. Valuation appears attractive at an EV/EBITDA of 16.5x and PE of 25x 2019e. Moreover, Wirecard trades at the lowest valuation multiples relative to its growth in the payment sector, with a PEG of 0.7x 2019e, on our estimates, vs the sector average of 1.5x.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Nothing to see here. Quick, back to fundamentals.

wayneJ Also given this is a Dec year end company an investigation starting in April would presumably have been finished and completed and presented by now? Or am I missing something?
BE11:31am

Barclays ....

BE11:31am

Wirecard’s rebuttal suggests that strong internal and external procedures are in place which is counter to the FT’s suggestions that Wirecard “accounting and internal controls have dogged the company for more than a decade”. It appears that the whistleblower doesn’t agree with this potential outcome and has brought the investigation to the attention of the FT.

We have an OW on the stock on its strong fundamentals and market positioning. We do not take a stance on the current allegations as we simply do not have the data required to make an appropriate judgment. However, we are of the opinion that the FT should have published its complete findings in a single article and not drip feed potential MNPI into the market which has caused great stock price volatility since the first article on Wednesday. Similarly, the emotional initial response from Wirecard is not helpful for investors, and whilst we fully understand it following these allegations it is simply adding fuel to the fire.

Pharma @chad_john, I'd be careful. No brexit or softer-than the May's already goose-down brexit will mean Corbyn. I don't expect that will be good for GBP.
11:32 am
BE11:32am

We should be looping in Gerardus Vos at Barclays on how to do reporting, apparently. Fair enough. Opinions are like etc.

BE11:33am

And now we wait for the Wirecard conference call at midday. Should be fun.

wayneJ And daft question - the grey say 'no conclusive findings of criminal misconduct on the part of any officer or employee of the Company' - does that exclude civil misconduct? And does it exclude non-employees (eg consultants or third parties)? And what does 'no conclusive' mean - what about suspicions? Am I over interpreting the statement?
undefined
Tom Dalgleish So what to make of the Royal relocation story of late?
chad_john @Pharma I don't think it means Corbyn, at best it means hung parliament. Oddly, I can see a scenario where the Torys win a majority if a GE is called soon.

Corporate governance has been a risk factor for Ferrexpo since forever, due to its concentrated shareholder base and various subsidiaries under the Fevamotinico banner.

Ryanair Holdings PLC (RYA:LSE): Last: 11.03, down 0.415 (-3.63%), High: 11.21, Low: 10.83, Volume: 1.17m
BE11:45am

Unexpectedly cautious about summer and with a board rejig.

DJ @wayne pesky yanks insist on "followed by the pound or hash key"
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Though with no explicit change to guidance.

BE11:46am

And I'll not get into whether Michael O’Leary signing a five-year contract is a positive or not.

BE11:46am

Here's Goodbody.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Ryanair’s warning of weaker summer yields will be seen as negative and suggests that the airline is still seeing some specific pricing issues; ‘We do not share the recent optimistic outlook of some competitors that Summer 2019 airfares will rise. In the absence of further EU airline failures .. we expect excess short haul capacity …will lead to a weaker – not stronger – fare environment.’ In this context, H120 sales to date have seen yields down 1% on average (vs GBY’s +1.1%).

BE11:47am

Q319 yields were in line with expectations at -6% yoy and clean PAT was a loss of €20m vs our €22m forecast (reported loss of €66m vs our €58m loss with slightly higher loss at Laudamotion). What was positive was the momentum behind ancillaries, which saw an increase in rev/pax of 17% yoy vs our 10% forecast. As such, total rev/pax was up 1.3% yoy vs our -1% forecast.

BE11:47am

In terms of trading, we believe that Ryanair needs to conclude a CLA with
BALPA, trade through to the Spring with no union disruption and keep the market informed on post-Easter yield developments to rebuild confidence. At that point we feel the market will once again place a premium on Ryanair’s sustainable business model, with FY20 costs expected to be down yoy (GBY -1%).

11:47 am
BE11:48am

And RBC.

BE11:48am

Ryanair has previously stated an intention ‘to lead fares down’ – to ‘drive fares down for customers... and…competitors’. With lower spot fuel likely to prolong excess supply and the industry shake-out into a fare destructive over supply backdrop we see Ryanair remaining an active discounter over summer 2019 – and thus likely improvement in YoY profits now delayed until autumn/winter 2019/20.

Plato the Cook @wayneJ it's a # key on US PC keyboards, £ key on UK PC keyboards. Just a relic from the days when the UK was important
BE11:48am

RBC Fundamental View
Fuel costs have fallen ~30% since their early October 2018 levels and are now down ~10% YoY on spot basis. We think lower spot fuel costs will likely see less rational (i.e. not profitable) capacity remain in the market longer.
In this environment we think balance sheet strength remains key to 3-year earnings power prospects (to outcompete, then harvest later more rational markets). Despite the testing short-term conditions we are thus OP on Ryanair as detailed in our note of EPS cuts as shake-out set to take longer – OP for the long-term prize, 16/01/2019. At ~12x FY18/19E, ~10x FY19/20E PER offers a limited entry opportunity into the potential of the business’s long-term earnings power.

VV75 yep, no pound key or sign on my keyboard

chad_john Aaahh
VV75 will probably be mandatory after brexit huh

BE11:59am

While our base case for the JS-Asda merger drives almost 60% pro-forma EPS accretion for SBRY, we expect synergies to be tempered by c.200 remedy store disposals (recent report here). Moreover, this provides a potential opportunity for both TSCO and MRW to acquire stores, with the latter benefiting from more opportunity and from a lower base.

Soundbuy Anybody cover Duke Royalty?
BE11:59am

So .....

Excel Developer In passing, Friday's US jobs numbers were good.
FATDAZ @wayneJ not the first time a company has been discussed here on that basis lol
11:59 am
BE11:59am

A mid-case remedy M&A scenario drives P-F EPS accretion of c.30% — Using our Synergy Adjusted Local GUPPI analysis, we have estimated MRW could buy between 48 and 108 remedy stores (incl. 32 to 73 large stores), with a mid-case of 78 stores representing 20% of MRW’s selling space (and 14% of Asda’s space). On the assumption that MRW will need to assume some additional costs (below store contribution) and will achieve towards 1% synergies, our mid-case store acquisition scenario drives c.30% P-F EPS accretion, before any reinvestment into the offer.

Grouchmonkey Erm any actual comment on Ryanair? Or is it just me that got a price and nothing else?

While we view Sainsbury’s shares as offering the best risk/reward from the potential merger, we recognize the benefit which might also accrue to Morrison’s. Accordingly, we upgrade our rating to Neutral. Our 255p TP reflects a sector PER 15x FYJan-20E EPS and our existing 75% merger probability applied to c.30% P-F accretion, discounted back by 2yrs.
